title: 107_hr654
content:
The "Immigration Services Consumer Protection Act of 2001" includes sections on short title, definitions, criminal penalties for immigration consultants, exceptions for attorneys and recognized organizations, community outreach programs, non-preemption of state laws, confidentiality of information, and effective date. The "Immigration Services Consumer Protection Act of 2001" defines key terms such as attorney, compensation, and immigration consultant, outlining the scope of assistance they can provide in immigration matters. The "Immigration Services Consumer Protection Act of 2001" defines an immigration matter as any proceeding, filing, or action affecting immigration or citizenship status under relevant laws. This includes services such as completing forms, submitting forms to authorities, making referrals to attorneys, and arranging for photographs or fingerprints. The "Immigration Services Consumer Protection Act of 2001" defines immigration matters and services provided by consultants. The "Immigration Services Consumer Protection Act of 2001" outlines requirements for immigration consultants, including the need for a consultant license issued by the Immigration and Naturalization Service and a written contract for each client. Failure to meet these requirements can result in fines, imprisonment, or both. The "Immigration Services Consumer Protection Act of 2001" requires immigration consultants to have a written agreement with clients that includes a description of services, payment amounts, a bold statement that the consultant is not an attorney, and a conspicuous statement in English and the client's language. The agreement must include a statement that the client has the right to rescind within 72 hours. It should not guarantee any outcomes with Immigration Services or the Attorney General. A notice must be displayed in the office meeting area. The person must display a notice not smaller than 12 inches by 20 inches in boldface print, including their license information and a statement that they are not an attorney. They must notify Immigration and Naturalization Service of any address changes within 30 days, deliver all completed documents to the client, and return any original documents upon request. The person must deliver all completed documents to the client that were provided for services. SEC. 4. EXCEPTION FOR ATTORNEYS, REPRESENTATIVES OF RECOGNIZED ORGANIZATIONS, AND OTHERS; RECOGNITION AND ACCREDITATION OF REPRESENTATIVES. In General, Section 3(a) exceptions include attorneys, law students, and law graduates not yet admitted to the bar, under specific conditions. Law students and law graduates can appear on behalf of a person under specific conditions, such as being supervised by a licensed attorney or accredited representative and appearing without payment. Official permission may be required for their appearance. The Attorney General establishes a process for recognizing qualified organizations and accrediting representatives, including accredited officials and individuals from recognized organizations. A grandfather clause applies to those authorized to practice before the Board of Immigration Appeals and the Immigration and Naturalization Service before December 23, 1952. The Attorney General establishes a process for recognizing nonprofit organizations and accrediting representatives to provide immigration services. Organizations must demonstrate adequate knowledge, information, and experience to be recognized. The Attorney General establishes an application process for recognizing organizations and accrediting representatives with good moral character and sufficient knowledge of immigration law to represent clients in immigration matters. The Attorney General may require periodic submission of applications or information from representatives. Recognition or accreditation may be withdrawn if qualifications are not maintained. The process should align with current standards set by the Board of Immigration Appeals. The Attorney General may require periodic submission of applications or information from representatives for recognition or accreditation, which may be withdrawn if qualifications are not maintained. Section 3 of the Act does not apply to individuals who do not receive compensation for services provided. SEC. 5. EDUCATION THROUGH COMMUNITY OUTREACH PROGRAMS.

The Attorney General can grant funds to States for community outreach programs to educate immigration consultant users about this Act.

SEC. 6. NON-PREEMPTION OF MORE PROTECTIVE STATE LAWS.

This Act supersedes State laws only if they conflict with section 3, and States can add additional requirements.

SEC. 7. CONFIDENTIALITY OF INFORMATION. The Attorney General and Department of Justice officials cannot use information provided by individuals, including undocumented aliens, for purposes other than enforcing the Act. Information from undocumented aliens cannot be used to identify or remove them from the US unless it is false. The Immigration and Naturalization Service files cannot be used for enforcement purposes, and using such information knowingly in violation of this rule can result in a fine of up to $10,000. The Act applies to actions taken as an immigration consultant on or after a date specified by the Attorney General, not later than 2 years after the enactment of the Act.
